Award.AwardTitle: RIDIR: Modernizing Political Event Data for Big Data Social Science Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project creates a general research platform to study civil protests, international conflict, and civil unrest using texts from Spanish, Arabic, and French, in addition to English. This expands the development of programs, data and services available for coding regional conflict and cooperation methods beyond the current English-only approaches to enable data-rich research that will advance new approaches to core questions in the social, behavioral, and economic sciences. The project includes an openly available website that allows for the extraction and reporting of conflict events across the globe as well as the identification of their causes and diffusion. The project's data and methods help make data-driven decisions about foreign policy, civil war prevention, human rights policies, and the effects of other factors such as environmental or economic policies on these phenomena.

The project creates large-scale civil and inter-state conflict measures, covering multiple news sources and with a common methodology in an open framework. Using multiple news data sources reduces the biases inherent in coding from a single or small set of news sources, a common approach in the past. The project aims to facilitate the coding of more, and better, data across languages, space and time, thus facilitating the study of substantive questions in traditionally underrepresented countries, peoples, and topics. Further, usability considerations generate new software for the user interface for dealing with big data like that proposed in this research, as well as server-side optimizations that scale large datasets across a diverse set of users. The scale of the event data, covering multiple years and large-scale news databases, will generate many millions of observations over space and time. Research tools, data extraction, and other user interfaces are developed to allow the relevant research communities to have access to, queries of, and citation streams for these data. Finally, machine-coded data from news reports is validated across news sources, languages, actors, ontologies, and against human-coded gold standard records. The research and data serve as inputs for understanding the effects of climate on spatio-temporally referenced civil conflict events in Latin American, Africa, the Middle East, and worldwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In our NSF RIDIR, we have developed a software suite and system architecture that is used to code what are known as event data. Event data in this context refers to a machine-coded description of someone doing something to someone else as extracted from news reports. In particular, we focus on political and social events about conflict and cooperation between individuals, non-governmental organizations, rebel groups, or governments, encoded using the Conflict Analysis and Mediation Ontology (CAMEO) (Gerner et al. 2009). 

The results of this work are reflected in the output of the Open Event Data Alliance, the software we have assembled on its related github site (Open Event Data Alliance, Open Event Data Alliance Github), and several associated publications (e.g., Solaimani et al. 2016, 2017a; Osorio, et al., 2019, D'Orazio, et al., 2018). This has culminated in our API data service that provides access to real-time streaming event d'roata coded from news reports (Salam, et al., 2019C). To date, this cyberinfrastructure platform allows access to millions of encoded political events across over 400+ news sources. 

Since coming online, we have delivered API credentials to over 170 users who have combined for over 62,000 requests. These users represent the broader event data community, including researchers from the United States, Europe, Israel, Turkey, China, and elsewhere. Universities, businesses such as Facebook, public institutions such as the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, and think tanks such as The Hague Centre of Strategic Studies, have all been provided with API access. This community is much larger than the subset of academic researchers publishing with event data. Furthermore, we expect this trend of increasing interest to continue.   We have made effort to expand our engagement with the broader research community. We hosted a workshop, with NSF support from the Society for Political Methodology, at the 2018 meeting of the American Political Science Association in Boston.

As part of the RIDIR, our multidisciplinary team of political and computer scientists has produced the Phoenix Real Time event data, the TERRIER event data, and a suite of tools to support the development of and access to these and other political event datasets. We list these tools below. 

1. UD-PETRARCH: this is our language agnostic event data coder that is able to code political events in the CAMEO in English, Spanish and Arabic based on universal dependency parses.

2. SPEC: Our Spark-based Political Event Coding pipeline that codes news reports metadata in real-time on XSEDE resources using UD-PETRARCH and provides an API to access the derived metadata on political and social conflict and cooperation around the globe (Solaimani, et al., 2016).

3. VTA: This is our Verb Translation Application for moving English language CAMEO and PETRARCH verb ontologies to additional languages (Osorio, et al., 2019 and Salam, et al., 2019A).

4. APART / RePAIR dictionary development tools: to code politically relevant event data we need a human in the loop step that identifies relevant political actors (Salam, et al., 2019B). We have developed two iterations of the recommendation algorithm, and are working to develop a stable application for human validations and annotations of the automated recommendations (Solaimani, et al., 2017a, 2017b).

5. TwoRavens for Event Data: This is a Web application that streamlines access and analysis of event data archives (Shoemate et. al., 2019A | Shoemate et. al., 2019B), including Phoenix, ICEWS, and the Cline Center data. Researchers at all levels of sophistication can construct database queries to build event datasets for analysis, guided by our interactive graphics that highlight distributional characteristics of the data and underlying features of the data (D'Orazio, et al., 2018).

6. UTDEventData R Library: This is an R library that provides direct access to our databases of event datasets (Hyoung, 2019). Using this library, researchers may query our event data API and load data into R for subsequent analysis. This allows more sophisticated users a direct lingua franca to the data.

7. V-PEP: Verb-pattern extension project, where we extend the CAMEO pattern dictionary by observing patterns that are not listed and represents interaction happening between known political actors. This, in conjunction to APART/RePAIR project, will help us to increase coverage on the generated event data.

8. PRoFILE - Primary Focus Location Extraction tool: This program identifies the geographic location of an event generated using UD Petrarch (Bahojb Imani, 2019). The software is capable of identifying the primary focus location by solving the problem of geographic disambiguation through a bias correction technique (Bahojb Imani, et al., 2017).
